docs.lead_paragraph: After years of trimming various projects and programs, Governor Whitman offered a budget last week that recommends spending a little more here and a little more there for the second year in a row. The strong economy is largely responsible for this largess. Hundreds of millions of dollars in additional tax revenue is pouring into the state's already overflowing coffers, giving Mrs. Whitman more than $1.1 billion to spend in the fiscal year starts July 1.

headline.main: Winners and Losers in the Governor's Budget

docs.abstract: Gov Christine Whitman's budget plan calls for increased spending in number of areas, taking benefit of New Jersey's strong economy; list of some key proposals; her photo (M)
docs.snippet: After years of trimming various projects and programs, Governor Whitman offered a budget last week that recommends spending a little more here and a little more there for the second year in a row.    The strong economy is largely responsible for this...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton and Republican leaders are devising plans to shore up the Social Security system. But neither the President nor his opponents are saying much about how to rescue Medicare, the entitlement program that is in deeper fiscal peril and poses even more unappealing political choices. Under current trends, Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund, which pays hospital bills for the elderly and is supported mostly by payroll taxes, will be depleted by 2012. Mr. Clinton's plan to use roughly $650 billion of the projected $4.4 trillion Federal surplus over the next 15 years to support Medicare may stave off insolvency for a few more years, but it will not solve the long-term problem of immense new costs when baby boomers begin needing Medicare.
docs.abstract: Editorial notes that while Pres Clinton and Republicans leaders are devising plans to shore up Social Security, they are not saying much about how to rescue Medicare, entitlement program that is in deeper financial peril and poses even more unappealing political choices; reviews various proposals and concerns that radical restructuring might produce system more chaotic and less protective of the poor (M)
docs.snippet: President Clinton and Republican leaders are devising plans to shore up the Social Security system. But neither the President nor his opponents are saying much about how to rescue Medicare, the entitlement program that is in deeper fiscal peril and...

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE was a time when many of the supervisors of Westchester's towns were re-elected again and again. Whether they were Democrats or Republicans, they were institutions. Last month with the death of Anthony L. Veteran, who served nine two-year terms from 1974 to 1991 as supervisor of the county's largest town, Greenburgh, the coterie of Westchester supervisors who have served more than a decade has dwindled to five. Just one of them, John A. Lombardi of North Castle, remains in office, completing his 19th two-year term. Collectively, the longtime town supervisors understood the county, said Herman D. Geist, a former chairman of the Board of Legislators who served four years as chairman from 1970 to the end of 1973. ''They had years of knowledge, a sense of history.'' Mr. Geist, who now lives in North Castle, recalled recently. ''I still drop in on Jack Lombardi, and he knows what I'm talking about. Some of these new supervisors -- and they're really bright -- don't know their history.''

headline.main: The Number of Longtime Town Supervisors Is Dwindling

docs.abstract: Number of longtime town supervisors in Westchester County, New York, dwindles with recent death of Anthony L Veteran of Greenburgh; list of those remaining includes John A Lombardi of North Castle, now completing his 19th two-year term; photos (M)
docs.snippet: THERE was a time when many of the supervisors of Westchester's towns were re-elected again and again. Whether they were Democrats or Republicans, they were institutions.  Last month with the death of Anthony L. Veteran, who served nine two-year terms...

docs.lead_paragraph: Q. After deciding that the insurance industry was not where I wanted to be, I took night classes for four years to complete an M.B.A. in market research. Alas, the degree seems to make no difference to prospective employers, who focus instead on my lack of experience and as a result are talking about salary levels way below what I now earn. Is there any way to make this less painful? A. You may be older and wiser and have better credentials than when you first entered the job force, but the fundamentals of the job market remain the same: Experience is key. You may need to fine-tune your job search -- and your attitude.
docs.abstract: Experts offer advice to a reader who took night classes to earn an MBA degree in market research only to find that prospective employers seem more interested in experience (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans leaders are accusing President Clinton of budget gimmickry, saying his plan to shore up reserves in the Social Security trust fund is an accounting trick. Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, says the President's plan ''appears to double count the Social Security surpluses,'' somehow extending the life of the trust fund ''without doing anything.''
docs.abstract: News analysis of Republican charge that Pres Clinton's plan to shore up Social Security reserves is accounting trick that 'appears to double count' surpluses to extend trust fund; Clinton's plan does double count surpluses, but this has been done in Federal budget for years; real difference now is that many Republicans want to use surplus to cut taxes or create individual retirement accounts, while liberals want to fund other programs, and Clinton himself wants to drive down Federal debt (M)
docs.snippet: Republicans leaders are accusing President Clinton of budget gimmickry, saying his plan to shore up reserves in the Social Security trust fund is an accounting trick.    Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Eight months after he began construction of an office tower on the Jersey City waterfront, the developer Richard S. LeFrak has lured two companies and almost 1,000 employees from Manhattan to the building. Cigna Corporation and the United States Trust Company of New York have signed leases for more than half the available space in the 14-story building at the Newport Office Center, Mr. LeFrak said yesterday.

headline.main: Metro Business; 2 Companies to Move Offices to Jersey City
